 BOSNIA AND HERZEGOVINA SECOND EMERGENCY EDUCATION RECONSTRUCTION PROJECT TECHNICAL ANNEX A. Reconstruction Progress to Date Primary School Reconstruction Program Update 1. In December, 1995, The Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina established a priority reconstruction program, which called for repair or reconstruction of damaged facilities at all levels of the education system. The total costs of this program were estimated at US$180 million. This original program did not include school reconstruction needs for the Republika Srpska (RS) because there was, at that time, no agreed primary school reconstruction program for the RS. The priority program has since been expanded to include priority reconstruction needs in the Republika Srpska. The total costs of this expanded priority program are estimated at US$275 million. This priority program includes 91 primary schools which the Federation Government aimed to reconstruct as the first phase of reconstruction, prior to the start of the 1996-97 school year. Actual primary school reconstruction under the priority program has fallen short of that goal, due principally to the lack of donor financing. Financing has already been provided for 52 of the 91 primary schools in the Federation's priority program. A total of US$10 million has been provided by the World Bank under the first Emergency Education Reconstruction Project 1 for reconstruction of 28 primary schools throughout the Federation. Reconstruction of these schools is nearly complete. An additional US$10.5 million has been committed to reconstruct 24 primary schools and provide school furniture and equipment by the Governments of Holland, Greece, and Malaysia, USAID, EU/ECHO and various NGOs. A financing gap of approximately US$13 million remains to reconstruct the remaining 39 primary schools in this priority program. Books and Educational Materials Support 2. The Government's priority program also includes provision of textbooks and supplementary readers to primary and secondary schools in the Bosniac-majority areas of the Federation 2 The program calls for the provision to schools in these areas of 72 textbook titles and 40 supplementary reader titles, and various other educational materials. This goal has been only partially achieved due to a lack of external financing. To date, approximately US$1.5 million in World Bank financing and US$0.2 million in Dutch Trust Fund financing has been committed to publishing and printing 20 textbooks and various educational materials which are in the process of being delivered to Bosnian classrooms. The Soros Foundation has agreed to finance US$0.8 million in supplementary readers and five English language training books, and several other donors have expressed interest in providing support for training books in other foreign languages. This leaves unfunded approximately 40 textbook titles, 30 supplementary reader titles, and various other educational materials under the Federation's priority program. Support for Project Implementation and Capacity Building 3. Althougth financing of the first Emergency Education Reconstruction Project is incomplete, implementation of the financed portions of the Project has been highly satisfactory. With support from various sources -- including the International Management Group (IMG), the Project Implementation Unit (PIU) of the Emergency Recovery Project, a consultant project management and procurement advisor, and Bank staff from the Bosnia Resident Mission -- the Education PIU has committed over 90 percent of project funds within three months of the effectiveness date of grant financing.3 Approximately 70 percent of World Bank funding was disbursed by the end of CY 1996. Government-managed trust funds provided by the Government of the Netherlands have been used to finance textbook pre-printing costs, PIU operating costs and works supervision, as well as limited office equipment and vehicles. Additional office equipment and vehicles have been procured for the PIU and local pedagogical institutes using World Bank Grant and IDA, Credit financing. PIU staff have developed project management skills to prepare and implement future investment projects financed by the Bank and other donors. UNDP will contract both PIUs shortly, to implement the reconstruction of 10 schools (seven in the Federation and three in RS), for US$2.0 million being provided by the Government of Japan. 4. In addition to building capacity for project management, World Bank-managed trust funds are being used to promote further analysis and policy reform in several important sub-sectors. In the field of teacher training, the Bank is supporting a joint initiative with UNICEF/USAID, the United States Information Agency and the Soros Foundation to expose local experts to teacher training innovations outside BH and to develop proposals for reform of the teacher training system. The Bank and the EU's European Training Foundation are jointly financing a review of the secondary technical and vocational education system. This initiative will help develop needed reforms as BH makes the transition from emergency reconstruction assistance to long term development of the education system. Trust Funds provided by the Government of the Netherlands are also being used to review the textbook production and financing system, and to finance study tours designed to expose local experts to innovations in the textbook field in other transition economies throughout Eastern and Central Europe. In addition to the primary school reconstruction programs, both the Federation and the RS have prepared priority secondary and higher education reconstruction programs for 1997. Needs estimates in 1997 for these levels are about US$40 million for the Federation and about US$20 million for the RS, each estimated to represent about 50 percent of highest priority reconstruction needs in those subsectors. While emergency financing is needed for secondary and higher education, donors have been cautioned in various fora, including the Education Task Force and the Brussels donor conferences, that significant investment at these levels should be linked to needed reforms to improve the responsiveness of secondary and higher education to the needs of an emerging market economy. This is particularly necessary in the case of specialized secondary technical and vocational schools, which need significant changes to respond to employment needs in new sectors and new markets. 7. Concurrent with emergency physical infrastructure rehabilitation programs, efforts are ongoing at all levels to upgrade education management and governance and improve the quality of education delivered in Bosnian schools. Education governance in Bosnia-Herzegovina remains in a state of flux as the roles and responsibilities of the various levels of government -- Entities, cantons (in the Federation) and regions/municipalities (in RS) -- continue to evolve. Preparation and implementation of the first Emergency Education Reconstruction Project has helped to facilitate contacts between the Federation MOE and the cantons/municipalities, but there is an urgent need to clarify the roles of various levels of government in providing education, as well as the appropriate sources of financing for education.

The Federal and RS MOEs are committed to increasing their capacity to coordinate investments in the sector and to focus donor support, where feasible, on priority programs in primary education. The preparation of the 1997 reconstruction programs, described above, reflect that commitment. The broad goals of the reconstruction program in both the Federation and RS remain the same as under the first Emergency Education Reconstruction Project: to make fully functional those classrooms which were damaged by the war, to restore effective teaching capacity by providing minimal supplies of textbooks, supplementary readers, and educational materials, and to support the resumption of minimal salaries for teachers. At the same time, both the Federation and RS MOEs are continuing their efforts to build institutional capacity to manage and coordinate the reconstruction effort and to deal with longer-term policy issues. 9. Although the emphasis in the Federation and RS continues to be on emergency reconstruction needs, government authorities in the Federation are beginning to address a number of key long term policy issues.4 Technical assistance, study tours and training are being provided through Bank-managed Dutch Trust Fund financing in the following areas: (1) a review of secondary technical and vocational education and adult training was recently completed by the European Training Foundation and presented to the Government and donors in April 1997, and should provide the background for policy dialogue on secondary VET issues during 1997; (2) a multi-donor supported Teacher Training Reform Initiative, implemented by the University of Pittsburgh, has successfully brought together authorities from all Federation cantons to begin to address structure and content reforms in pre-service and in-service teacher training, and will be presented to the Government and the donors at the end of June 1997; and (c) pilot textbook production and cost recovery programs have been developed by International Book Development (IBD), implementation of which will be financed under this proposed project. In addition, key sector policy issues are being pursued under various actions carried out under the Education Sector Reconstruction Task Force, which comprises the Government and the main donor agencies active in the education sector (including the EU, ECHO, UNDP, USAID, UNHCR, UNICEF, UNESCO, IMG and the Soros Foundation, and the Bank). It is expected that future investments in the education sector will focus on rebuilding and refocusing secondary school facilities in the context of a broader secondary education reform, as well as reorienting teacher training and reforming textbook financing and production. Project Sustainability 10. The key question of sustainability for the investments which the Project will support is whether the responsible authorities will have the resources necessary to operate the project schools effectively in the future. This means, in particular, whether they will be able to attract and retain qualified teachers, and whether they will have the budgets necessary to pay for utilities, replenishment of educational materials, and school maintenance. In the course of appraising this Project, data were collected from all of the Federation cantons and from the Republika Srpska concerning the availability of teachers and local capacities to pay teachers and to provide for other recurrent needs. These data reveal that, in general, schools are adequately supplied with teachers; three-quarters of the teachers currently in place are fully qualified under prevailing teacher training requirements. Throughout the Federation, primary-school teachers are being paid by the cantons an average of DM 250 per month; secondary school teachers are being paid an average of DM 300 per month. A few cantons are already paying for utilities and other recurrent costs; others plan to do so. In the Republika Srpska, teachers are also being paid, but they receive, on average, only a third as much as teachers in the Federation. 11. Contrary to expectations, these recent figures confirm that teachers are being paid throughout the country at this early stage in the recovery process. This is encouraging evidence that local revenue bases are beginning to recover, and that local budget authorities consistently give a high priority to the most urgent recurrent financing needs of schools. For the medium term, however, there is a clear need to develop secure financing for utilities and other recurrent costs of schools which are not now being met. In the current rapidly evolving budget situation, an important question is whether local revenues will be adequate to finance these needs and continue to provide adequately for teachers' salaries. Several activities are planned in the coming year to help ensure that there are adequate resources for education and other key public services in the future. The Public Expenditure Review which the Bank carried out with counterparts in both Entities in early May 1997 examines revenues and expenditures of central and cantonal governments, and recommend measures for increasing tax yields and improving the efficiency of the budgetary process. Implementation of these measures would be supported under a planned investment operation and a planned policy-based operation later in 1997. In addition, the proposed Second Emergency Education Reconstruction Project would address the needs for financial sustainability of education by supporting several actions to strengthen education finance and administration: a) carrying out of a study of options for education finance and administration, looking at the experiences of other decentralized education systems in relation to the decentralization experience under the Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia, b) dissemination of findings of the study through preparation of a report and presentation of a national seminar, and c) supporting consensus- building for the recommended measures through local seminars, study visits, etc. Conduct of the study under agreed terms of reference and an agreed time schedule, and implementation of the recommendations of the study would be conditions of the proposed Second Emergency Education Reconstruction Project. Continued implementation of the recommendations of the Education Finance and Administration Study would also be supported through conditionality in a planned policy-based project in support of public expenditure reform. 12. Other education policy issues are being addressed by ongoing initiatives of the Education Reconstruction Task Force, with Bank participation. Bank-executed trust fund financing provided by the Government of the Netherlands is being used to support policy development in the areas of secondary technical and vocational education, teacher training, and textbooks, with the aim of improving educational quality and making the delivery of education more efficient and cost-effective. It is expected that investments to implement these policies will be supported under subsequent Bank- financed operations, as well as by other donors. IBRD/IDA Assistance Strategy 13. Experience gained from the first Emergency Education Reconstruction Project has confirmed the importance of working closely with central education authorities to prepare a consolidated investment program for each of Bosnia's two Entities. This approach has served to build institutional capacity for central authorities to assume a coordination role, and has facilitated regular communications between the central level and cantons and municipalities. It has also served to begin the process of re-orienting aid flows for education away from uncoordinated activities driven by donor
 - 6 - preferences toward adoption of a priority reconstruction program established by the Government and endorsed by the donor community. This process has had the additional positive impact of helping to bring together the two partners of the Federation to participate in investment programming and implementation. It is expected that this proposed second project will have a similar influence in facilitating cooperation between the Federation and the RS. 14. In light of the limited IDA-ITF resources allocated to the education sector in Bosnia (US$11.0 million) and the under-funding of the school reconstruction program, the Bank has decided, in consultation with the Government and key education donors, to proceed immediately with the Second Emergency Education Reconstruction Project (FY97), aimed largely at filling the financing gap for the first project, and supporting school reconstruction in the Republika Srpska. The commitment of Bank funding to the 1997 program (which includes the financing gap from the first project) is expected to have a catalytic influence in encouraging other donors to commit to the Government's priority education reconstruction program, first for the remaining US$6.0 million needed to rehabilitate schools on the Federation's original list, and then to address the additional requirements of the next group of 140 severely damaged primary schools. Concurrently, the Bank will begin preparation of a third education project which would, in addition to continuing support for reconstruction, address longer- term sectoral issues such as improved financing and administration, and structural changes to improve the relevance of secondary education. IDA-ITF funding under the Second Emergency Education Reconstruction Project was expected to be made available by the beginning of the construction season in March 1997. However, macro-economic conditionality has delayecl Board presentation until June 1997, and a good portion of the construction season has been lost. Therefore, the Project will have to complete construction activities to be initiated during this construction season, during Spring/Summer 1998. Funding for the third project will depend on the availability of IDA-ITF funding in 1997/98. Significant cofinancing is needed for both projects, as well as for the first Emergency Education Reconstruction Project. C. Detailed Project Description 15. The objective of the proposed Second Emergency Education Reconstruction Project is to improve primary education access and quality by reconstructing primary schools throughout Bosnia and Herzegovina, including schools which are ready for tendering but for which financing was not available under the first Emergency Education Reconstruction Project, and damaged schools in the Republika Srpska. This financing will help achieve the first project's objective of helping to restore the delivery of primary education of acceptable quality to the children of BH. The proposed project would support the reconstruction of 18 primary schools from the unfinanced portion of the Federation's 1996 priority program; other donors are expected to finance the other schools on the 1997 priority list. It would also finance the reconstruction of about 7 heavily damaged primary schools in the Republika Srpska. The financing provided under the Second Emergency Education Reconstruction Project would meet only about 13 percent of estimated total school reconstruction needs at all levels in the Federation and in RS during 1997. Project resources have been allocated throughout the Federation and RS on the basis of population. Within cantons and municipalities, project resources are allocated on the basis of local priorities for education reconstruction. 16. A detailed cost table for the proposed project is provided in Appendix 1. Implementation and institutional responsibilities are described in Section D. The Project would provide: (a) financing for reconstruction of about 25 primary schools in the Federation and RS (estimated cost, US$8.1 million); (b) the provision of furniture for classrooms in these schools
 - 7 - (estimated cost, US$1.0 million); (c) the provision of textbooks and other educational materials for Federation schools (estimated cost, US$0.8 million); (d) technical assistance in Education Finance and Administration (US$0.5 million); and (e) incremental costs of project management (US$0.4 million). The proposed project would meet about US$7 million of the US$13 million financing gap for the reconstruction of Federation schools under the First Emergency Education Reconstruction Project, leaving a financing gap of about US$6 million to be met from foreign sources. School Rehabilitation and Furnishing 17. Construction will be carried out by local construction contractors to be selected on a competitive basis. Architectural designs and specifications are being developed through IMG, using UNDP financing. Estimated reconstruction costs under the proposed project reflect recent experience under the first Emergency Education Reconstruction Project, in which reconstruction costs have been about US$400 per square meter on average. According to a study conducted by the Bank's Resident Mission in Sarajevo, these costs are lower than the average costs of school reconstruction financed by NGOs during the project period in BH. The cost of school furniture, financed under the first project by the EU, was about US$4,000 per classroom, based on a classroom size to accommodate 32 students. 18. War-damaged schools to be reconstructed under the proposed project in the Federation were selected and agreed with the Bank during preparation of the first Emergency Education Reconstruction Project, based on the criteria of: a) light-to-medium war-related damage which could be repaired quickly, and b) the absence of other facilities which could accomodate the school-age children in the catchment area. (A list of the specific schools selected for rehabilitation and reconstruction under the project is available upon request.) Schools have been selected for this second project using criteria which have been modified to include more severely damaged schools, as well as schools in UNHCR priority areas for the return of refugees and displaced people. As the agency responsible for overseeing the school reconstruction process at the Federation level, the MOE took the lead in defining criteria for selecting schools and reaching agreement on the criteria with the Bank, as well as for working with canton-level education ministries and other education authorities (in those areas where canton-level ministries of education were not yet formed) to apply the criteria to the needs of the various municipalities. Selection of primary schools for reconstruction in the RS has been carried out by the RS MOE, in cooperation with RS regions/municipalities and the Urban Institute of Banja Luka, using the same selection criteria and procedures as agreed with the Federation. Funding for supplementary readers and educational materials agreed under the first project has, for the most part, not been forthcoming by donors. 20. The Federation MOE has agreed to procure textbooks to be financed under the second project through pilot schemes aimed at competitive selection of published manuscripts. Pilots will also be conducted to test limited cost recovery through rental of textbooks to students, and to promote competitition in preparation of educational manuscripts. Education Finance and Administration 21. The March, 1994 Washington Agreement which estalblished the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and the November, 1995 Dayton Accord which established the State of Bosnia and Herzegovina stipulate that education in the Federation is the responsibility of the ten cantons comprising the Federation. But these documents explicitly provide for the delegation of particular educational responsibilities upwards to the Federation or downwards to individual municipalities, upon agreement by the cantons. There has been little systematic discussion of the need for delegating other particular functions to the Federation or to municipalities. This need could arise for several reasons, including the need to ensure the quality and consistency of education programs, to capture economies of scale, to ensure the consistency of education quality by region, and to promote nationbuilding. Although the Republika Srpska has a unitary government and does not face the same questions as the Federation concerning the role of regional governments, there is, nonetheless, a need to clarify the role of the RS Ministry of Education in establishing education policy and ensuring the necessary financing for education programs. 22. This component will address the need to clarify the roles of the various levels of government -- Entities, the Federation cantons, and RS regions/municipalities -- in providing and financing education. It will do so by supporting local and foreign consultant services (estimated cost, US$0.5 million) to: (a) carry out a study of options for education finance and administration, looking at the experiences of other decentralized education systems in relation to the decentralization experience under the Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia; (b) disseminate study findings through preparation of a report and presentation of a national seminar; and (c) support corsensus-building for the recommended measures through local seminars, study visits, etc. Carrying out of the study and subsequently implementing its recommendations is to be a condition of project implementation (paragraph 47). Hazardous materials such as asbestos will not be used in school construction or rehabilitation under the Project. D. Institutional Arrangements and Implemrentation Project lImplementation 28. Implementation arrangements will be the same as those used for the successful implementation of the first Emergency Education Reconstruction Project.5 A Project Implementation Unit (PIU) located in the Federation MOE is responsible for managing the on-going program in the Federation. The PIU has successfully managed US$9.2 million in civil works and educational materials contracting under the first project, and will continue to manage the supplementary funding for activities in the Federation provided under this project, including maintaining appropriate records as the basis for periodic project audits. The PIU will continue to be supported by the professional project management and procurement advisor who provided implementation support under the first project. Technical staff of the PIU will continue to be responsible for overseeing and coordinating the reconstruction programs with canton and municipality level officials. They will also continue to work closely with other agencies providing implementation assistance. 29. A PIU is established under similar organization and procedures in the Republika Srpska MOE to manage implementation of those funds allocated to the primary school reconstruction effort in RS. The project management and procurement advisor will also support this unit. Every effort will be made to share experiences and documentation between the two Entities. A detailed implementation schedule for all components is provided in Appendix 2. 30. Primary School Reconstruction Component. The primary school reconstruction component will be managed by the Federation PIU's reconstruction unit, which has managed US$8.0 million in civil works contracting under the first project. A similar unit is being established under the RS PIU. The Federation PIU's reconstruction unit is made up of three architect/engineers. It has already verified school rehabilitation priorities for project funding with the cantons and managed the preparation of architectural assessments, designs and cost estimates with the support of the International Management Group, under UNDP funding. Once supplementary funding is approved under the Project for the priority schools already selected, this unit will a) formulate bid packages and prepare bidding documents (largely completed); b) evaluate bids, recomnmend bid awards, and negotiate contracts, and c) manage the supervision of civil works. As with the first project, the unit will continue to receive support for managing works supervision from civil engineers provided by the NATO Peace Stabilization Force (SFOR). The actual supervision will be carried out by local contractors selected competitively by the PIU and paid for under the credit. The reconstruction unit will also take responsibility for furniture procurement including defining specifications and coordinating procurement and delivery of furniture in cooperation with canton-level educational authorities. Implementation of this component is to be managed by the Federation PIU's educational materials unit, which successfully managed about US$1.5 million in textbook and educational materials procurement under the first Emergency Education Reconstruction Project. MOE's Chief Editor will act as the principal counterpart to consultants supporting the design and implementation of textbook production and financing pilots based on competitive selection of private sector publishers and limited cost recovery over the short term. Working with consultants provided by IBD in London (financed by the Government of the Netherlands), the Editor will be responsible for assuring content, quality and acceptability of textbooks and educational materials proposed by private sector publishers. The Editor will organize the competitive selection of published books and supplies, as well as their delivery to canton-level warehouses. Procurement 32. Procurement arrangements are summarized in the table below and a procurement plan is attached in Appendix 3. Project procurement is to be made mainly through National Competitive Bidding (NCB), Simplified National Competitive Bidding (SNCB), and National Shopping (NS). 33. Advertising. A General Procurement Notice (GPN) was published in Development Business in June 1996 for the first project; it will be repeated for the proposed project. The notice will include information about the nature of the goods, works and services to be procured under the primary school reconstruction program and invite interested and eligible suppliers, contractors and consultants to send their expression of interest to the Federation and RS PIUs. The GPN will also be re-published in the local press and distributed to embassies. The GPN will be followed by specific advertisements, in the local press and distributed to embassies, for individual contracts where necessary. Bidding documents will be sent to suppliers who respond to the GPN and the specific advertisements. 34. Goods. Local suppliers of school furniture, books and educational materials proved responsive and competitive under the first Emergency Education Reconstruction Project, which relied heavily on National Shopping. Goods procurement under this proposed project will rely more heavily on National Competitive Bidding procedures, as follows: a. National Competitive Bidding (NCB). NCB procedures, requiring local advertisement, will be used for school furniture, equipment, books and materials estimated to cost between US$100,000 and US$1.0 million per contract, in accordance with Bank guidelines, up to an aggregate limit of US$300,000 for the Federation and US$200,000 for the RS. b. National Shopping (NS). NS will be used for contracts for goods available in Bosnia Herzegovina up to an estimated cost of US$100,000 per contract, with at least three quotations, and up to an aggregate limit of US$300,000 for the Federation and US$200,000 for the RS c. Direct Contracting (DC). DC will be used for proprietary items, for reasons of compatibility and standardization, and in any other justified case. Any direct contracting to be financed by the IDA credit will need prior Bank approval. 35. Recurrent Costs/Incremental Operating Costs. Recurrent Costs and Incremental Operating Costs are currently being financed under a Dutch Trust Fund and under the first Emergency
 - 12 - Education Reconstruction Project. A small amount of funds -- US$400,000 -- has been set aside under the proposed project to finance these activities at rates of remuneration established by the Reconstruction Board as recurrent cost financing is exhausted from these other sources. 36. Works. Given the nature of civil works under the Project, mainly rehabilitation of existing facilities, Simplified National Competitive Bidding (SNCB) will be used for contracts estimated to cost up to US$0.2 million per contract up to an aggregate limit of US$2.4 million for the Federation and US$1.8 million for the RS. These works will be procured under lump-sum, fixed-price contracts awarded on the basis of quotations obtained from at least three qualified contractors in response to a written invitation. The invitation shall include a detailed description of works, including basic specifications, the required completion period, a basic form of agreement acceptable to IDA, and relevant drawings, where applicable. The award shall be made to the contractor who offers the lowest price quotation for the required work, and who has the experience and resources to successfully complete the contract within the specified time period. Any school construction contracts estimated to cost more than US$0.2 million but less than US$2.0 million up to an aggregate limit of US$2.3 million for the Federation and US$1.6 million for the RS would be awarded on the basis of advertised National Competitive Bidding. The contracting industry was well established throughout BH prior to the war. The experience under the first Emergency Education Reconstruction Project demonstrates that much of this capacity still exists. Thus, the civil works for school rehabilitation and reconstruction under the Project will be carried out in the customary manner -- through contracts with commercial construction enterprises. 37. Services. Services under the Project -- mainly for the supervision of works -- will be procured through a request for proposals from a short list of qualified firms/individuals. Qualified firms will be invited to submit proposals for comprehensive packages of consultant services and management of fellowships and training in accordance with the "Guidelines for the Use of Consultants by World Bank Borrowers and by The World Bank as Executing Agency" (August 1981). To keep the evaluation process manageable, no more than six (but at least three) proposals will be invited following a short listing acceptable to the Bank. 38. Procurement Implementation Capacity. Procurement performance has been satisfactory under the first Emergency Education Reconstruction Project. The need for hands-on assistance provided by the World Bank Resident Mission in Sarajevo, SFOR, and the project management and procurement advisor is expected to decline during, implementation of the proposed second project. However, this assistance, with the exception of the ERP support, will continue to be available to the Federation PIU, as well as to the PIU in the Republika Srpska, which is likely to need more hands-on support initially. 39. Prior and Post Bank Review of Procurement Documents. Prior review will be required for the first three contracts awarded through National Shopping (NS), Simplified National Competitive Bidding (SNCB), or National Competitive Bidding (NCB) for both the Federation and for RS. Prior review will also continue to be required for all contracts procured through Direct Contracting (DC).

To facilitate timely project implementation, payments for agreed project actions are to be made from two Special Accounts: one for the Federation and the other for RS. The currency of the Special Accounts will be US dollars. Resporisibility for making payments from the Special Accounts will continue to be delegated by the State. The authorized allocation of the Special Account for the Federation would be US$3.0 million, representing about four months of estimated average expenditures expected to be paid from the Special Account. This is consistent with the disbursement performance under the first Emergency Education Reconstruction Project. The authorized allocation of the Special Account for the RS would be US$1].75 million, also representing about four months of average expenditures to be paid from the account. Replenishment applications would continue to be forwarded to the Bank monthly and will include reconciled bank statements as well as other appropriate documents. For large contracts, the Bank would make direct payments to suppliers. 42. Statement of Expenditures. With the exception of direct contracting and the first three contracts awarding through National Shopping (NS), Simplified National Competitive Bidding (SNCB), or National Competitive Bidding (NCB), disbursements would be made against Statements of Expenditures (SOEs) for goods and civil works contracts of up to US$ 1.0 million. Disbursement against all recurrent expenditures under the Project will be made by Statement of Expenditures, as would all expenditures for consultant services amounting to less than US$100,000 for firms and US$50,000 for individuals. Detailed documents evidencing expenditures would be maintained in a central location by the PIUs for review by the required audit as well as Bank supervision missions. Disbursement for contracts requiring the Bank's prior review would be made against presentation to the Bank of full contract documentation. Project Audits, Accounting and Reporting 43. Accounts. Separate and auditable accounts would be established and maintained by the two PIUs for the Project. For each Entity, these accounts would include: (i) a record of withdrawals with copies of all disbursement requests and underlying documentation; and (ii) a record of transactions under the Special Account and copies of the bank statements pertaining to the account.
 - 15 - 44. Audits. The project accounts would be audited annually by independent auditors who shall be employed by November 30, 1997 under terms of reference acceptable to the Bank. Separate audit statements would be prepared for the Special Account and for Statements of Expenditures. All audit reports would be made available to the Bank within six months after the end of each fiscal year. Project accounts would be maintained for one year after they have been audited. 45. Reporting. The project PIUs will prepare and furnish to the Bank quarterly: a) progress reports showing the status of implementation of the Project, and b) financial reports in a format acceptable to the Bank. Supervision Plan 46. Project implementation will continue to require a large degree of flexibility in view of the rapidly changing circumstances in the country. In particular, procurement and disbursement issues will continue to require intensive supervision, particularly for the RS PIU, which has less experience with World Bank guidelines and procedures. Given the straightforward nature of the Project and the short implementation period, no midterm review will be required. To facilitate flexibility and rapid decision-making, the social sectors Bank staff located in the World Bank Resident Mission in Sarajevo and in the Human Resources Hub in Budapest, as well as headquarters-based staff, will continue to provide intensive supervision of initial project implementation, and will provide prompt feedback on matters requiring a decision by the Bank. Agreements Reached 47. Agreement was reached at Negotiations on the following points: a) that the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina and the Republika Srpska would: i) carry out by September 30, 1997 an Education Finance and Administration Study under terms of reference satisfactory to the Association; ii) provide to the Association for comment by October 31, 1997 the findings and recommendations of the Education Finance and Administration Study; and iii) subsequently implement the recommendations of the Study, as discussed and agreed with the Association; b) that the State, the Federation and RS shall employ independent auditors by November 30, 1997; c) that the Federation and RS shall coordinate with the Procurement Monitoring and Audit Unit for purposes of procurement monitoring and audit for their respective parts of the Project; d) that the Federation and RS shall by February 28 of each year prepare a report on the progress achieved in carrying out their respective parts of the Project and review such report, together with the Association, by March 31, 1998; and
 - 16 - e) that the execution of a Project Agreement between IDA and at least one of the Entities and the corresponding Subsidiary Credit Agreement between Bosnia and Herzegovina and such Entity would be a condition of effectiveness for the proposed ITF Credit. Execution of the Project Agreement between IDA and the other Entity and the corresponding Subsidiary Credit Agreement between Bosnia and Herzegovina and such Entity would be a condition of disbursement for that portion of the Credit allocated to that Entity. E. Benefits and Risks 48. Benefits. The proposed Second-Phase Implementation of the Emergency Education Reconstruction Project would help to restore the provision of education of acceptable quality throughout the Federation and RS, thereby improving the educational qualifications and future produptive potential of their school-age population. The Project would also improve the Government's capacity to manage education programs, and would continue to provide a framework for cooperation between the two partners of the Federation, and encourage similar cooperation between the Federation and the Republika Srpska. 49. Risks. The risk remains that a renewal of hostilities among the various partners of the new State and Federation could undermine implementation of the Project, and prevent (or severely delay) achievement of the Project's objectives. However, the reconstruction program itself is helping to reduce this risk by creating incentives for cooperation by all parties.

doc.abstracts: The primary objective of the Second Emergency Education Reconstruction Project for Bosnia and Herzegovina (the Federation) is to continue the work begun under the first project similarly named, which aimed to restore adequate teaching and learning conditions in the country's primary schools. Secondary objectives are to help develop an appropriate process of education finance and administration, to build government implementation capacity to plan and deliver education programs at different government levels, and to facilitate communication and cooperation on education issues within the Federation, and between the Federation and the Serb Republic. The project will support: 1) reconstruction of primary schools in the Federation and of about seven primary schools in the Serb Republic; 2) provision of classroom furniture and equipment; 3) provision of textbooks and educational materials for Federation schools; 4) support for incremental recurrent costs for the two project implementation units; and 5) technical assistance to improve education finance and administration.
